docs.title: Acoustic Manufacturing System
docs.text:
CONCEPTUAL PLANNING PHASE ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

Advanced Acoustic Levitation Manufacturing

Planned contactless material processing using ultrasonic transducer arrays

docs.title: 🎯 System Overview
docs.text:
The proposed Acoustic Manufacturing System would use 40 kHz ultrasonic transducers to create standing waves for contactless manipulation of molten metal droplets. This planned approach would enable:

  • Precision Control

    Targeted ±0.3mm droplet steering accuracy with planned real-time thermal feedback

  • Temperature Range

    Planned 700°C (Aluminum) to 1580°C (Steel) processing capability

  • Material Quality

    Target >95% theoretical density with planned controlled cooling rates

  • Scalable Design

    Planned modular progression from $14k prototype to $117k production system

docs.title: Coding Error Log - Jupyter Notebook Issues
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

docs.title: CRITICAL ERROR PATTERNS - DOCUMENT FOR FUTURE REFERENCE
Error #1: Missing Package Dependencies
docs.text: Error: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'plotly' Root Cause: Auto-installation code placed AFTER import statements Solution: Move auto-installation code BEFORE imports

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text:
import plotly.graph_objects as go  # FAILS HERE
try:
    import plotly.graph_objects as go
    # auto-install code here - TOO LATE!

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text:
# Try import first, install if missing, THEN import
try:
    import plotly.graph_objects as go
    PLOTLY_AVAILABLE = True
except ImportError:
    import subprocess
    subprocess.check_call([sys.executable, "-m", "pip", "install", "plotly"])
    import plotly.graph_objects as go
    PLOTLY_AVAILABLE = True

docs.title: Error #2: F-String Syntax Error
docs.text: Error: SyntaxError: f-string: single '}' is not allowed Root Cause: Incorrect f-string formatting with nested brackets Solution: Use separate variables for calculations

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text:
print(f"Margin: {12000 - total_power:,.0f}W ({(12000-total_power)/12000*100:.1f}%})")
#                                                                              ^^^ EXTRA }

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text:
margin = 12000 - total_power
margin_pct = (margin/12000)*100
print(f"Margin: {margin:,.0f}W ({margin_pct:.1f}%)")

docs.title: Error #3: String Literal Escape Issues
docs.text: Error: SyntaxError: unexpected character after line continuation character Root Cause: Using single backslashes in docstrings Solution: Use triple quotes consistently

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text:
def func():
    \"\"\"Docstring with escaped quotes\"\"\"  # WRONG - creates \" escape sequence

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text:
def func():
    """Docstring with proper quotes"""

docs.title: Error #4: Variable Scope Issues
docs.text: Error: NameError: name 'registry' is not defined Root Cause: Variables defined in one cell not available in another Solution: Ensure proper cell execution order and variable initialization

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text:
# Cell 1: registry = ComponentRegistry()
# Cell 3: for comp in registry.components:  # FAILS if Cell 1 not run

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text:
# Always check variable exists or reinitialize
if 'registry' not in globals():
    registry = ComponentRegistry()

docs.title: Error #5: EOL String Literal Error
docs.text: Error: SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal Root Cause: Missing closing quote in print statement Solution: Always match quotes properly

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text: print("Text without closing quote)  # MISSING "

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text: print("Text with proper closing quote")

docs.title: PREVENTION CHECKLIST
docs.text:
Before committing notebook changes:

  1. 📋 Import Order: Auto-install BEFORE imports
  2. 📋 F-String Validation: Test complex f-strings separately
  3. 📋 Quote Consistency: Use """ for docstrings, " for strings
  4. 📋 Variable Scope: Check cross-cell dependencies
  5. 📋 Syntax Validation: Run each cell before committing
  6. 📋 Error Handling: Include try/except for brittle operations

docs.title: Find f-string issues:
docs.text: grep -n "f\".*{.*{.*}.*}.*\"" *.ipynb

docs.title: Check for escape issues:
docs.text: grep -n '\\"' *.ipynb

docs.title: Validate Python syntax:
docs.text: jupyter nbconvert --to python notebook.ipynb --stdout | python -m py_compile -

docs.title: LESSONS LEARNED
docs.text:
1. Cell Order Matters: Jupyter cells must be executed in dependency order
  2. Import Strategy: Always handle missing dependencies before imports
  3. String Complexity: Break complex f-strings into multiple variables
  4. Testing First: Test each cell individually before combining
  5. Error Logs: Document these patterns to prevent recurrence

Next time these errors occur, reference this log for immediate resolution.

docs.title: Component: component_registry.py - Power Supply Unit
docs.text: Error: PSU listed as consuming 10kW instead of supplying 10kW Impact: Power budget showed 23.7kW consumption (impossible - exceeds supply) Root Cause: Conceptual error in power flow direction

docs.title: Incorrect Pattern:
docs.text:
# PSU specs - WRONG
tech_specs=TechnicalSpecs(
    power_consumption=10000,  # W output - WRONG FIELD!
Result: System shows 23.7kW total power consumption

docs.title: Correct Pattern:
docs.text:
# PSU specs - CORRECT
tech_specs=TechnicalSpecs(
    power_consumption=900,  # W input consumption (efficiency loss)
    # 10kW output capacity is implicit - PSU supplies power, doesn't consume it
Result: System shows 14.6kW total power consumption (realistic)

docs.title: KEY INSIGHT:
docs.text:
• Power supplies PROVIDE power, they don't CONSUME their rated capacity
  • PSU consumption = Input power - Output power = Efficiency losses
  • For 91% efficient 10kW PSU: Consumes ~900W, Supplies 10,000W

docs.title: VALIDATION CHECK:
docs.text:
# Quick power budget validation
python3 -c "from models.component_registry import ComponentRegistry; 
registry = ComponentRegistry(); 
power_budget = registry.calculate_power_budget(); 
total = power_budget['TOTAL']['active_power'];
print(f'Total Power: {total}W'); 
print('✅ Realistic' if total < 15000 else '❌ Check PSU accounting')"

This error caused completely incorrect power analysis - always verify supply vs consumption!

docs.title: ✅ FIXED: Added power_supply Field to TechnicalSpecs
docs.text:
Solution Implemented: 

@dataclass
class TechnicalSpecs:
    # Electrical
    power_consumption: Optional[float] = None  # Watts (power consumed by component)
    power_supply: Optional[float] = None  # Watts (power supplied by component, e.g., PSU)

PSU Updated: 

tech_specs=TechnicalSpecs(
    power_consumption=900,  # W input power consumption (efficiency losses)
    power_supply=10000,     # W output power supplied to system

Power Budget Calculator Enhanced: - Now tracks both consumption and supply separately - Calculates net power: net_power = active_power - power_supply - Shows true system power requirements

Result: - ✅ Total Consumption: 14.6kW - ✅ Total Supply: 10.0kW - ✅ Net Power Required: 4.6kW (54% margin available) - ✅ Notebook updated to use new calculation method

Lesson: Power supply components provide power to the system - they should have both consumption (efficiency losses) AND supply (capacity) fields.

docs.title: Acoustic Array
docs.text:
• Transducers: 10kHz ultrasonic, 25W per unit
  • Level 1: 18 units
  • Level 4: 72 units
  • Primary: APC International APC-10K-25W-HT
  • Lead time: 4 weeks

docs.title: Control System
docs.text:
• FPGA: Phase control for transducer array
  • Intel Cyclone V or Xilinx Artix-7
  • 72+ channels for Level 4
  • Lead time: 2-3 weeks

docs.title: Thermal Sensing
docs.text:
• IR Camera: See Thermal Camera Specifications
  • Lead time: 6 weeks (critical path)

docs.title: Thermal System (Level 2+)
docs.text:
• Induction Heater: Ambrell EASYHEAT
  • 8kW power
  • Water cooled
  • Lead time: 8 weeks (critical path)

docs.title: Phase 1: Long Lead Items (Week 1)
docs.text:
1. Optris PI 1M thermal camera
  2. Ambrell induction system (for Level 2)
  3. Custom transducers (if selected)

docs.title: Phase 2: Standard Components (Week 2-3)
docs.text:
1. FPGA development boards
  2. STM32 microcontrollers
  3. Power supplies and cooling

docs.title: Phase 3: Mechanical/Integration (Week 4+)
docs.text:
1. Chamber materials
  2. Mounting hardware
  3. Cables and connectors

docs.title: Volume Discounts
docs.text:
• Transducers: 5% at 50 units, 10% at 100 units
  • FPGAs: Better pricing at 100+ units
  • Consider bulk orders for Level 4

docs.title: Alternative Sourcing
docs.text:
• Piezo Technologies: Lower cost, longer lead
  • Used/refurbished thermal cameras
  • Academic discounts where applicable

docs.title: High Risk Components
docs.text:
1. Thermal Camera: Single source, high cost

  2. Mitigation: Order early, consider backup

  3. Induction System: Long lead time

  4. Mitigation: Start procurement in Week 1

  5. Custom Transducers: Unproven performance

  6. Mitigation: Order samples first

docs.title: Supply Chain Backup Plans
docs.text:
• Maintain alternate vendor options
  • Keep critical spares for Level 1
  • Document all custom modifications

git clone https://github.com/jnarwell/drip.git

docs.title: Acoustic Modeling
docs.text:
CONCEPTUAL PLANNING PHASE ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

docs.title: Field Parameters
docs.text:
• Frequency: 40 kHz ± 100 Hz
  • Wavelength: 8.58mm (in air at 20°C)
  • Pressure amplitude: 2-3 kPa
  • Acoustic power: 10W per transducer

docs.title: Acoustic Force Calculation
docs.text:
The acoustic radiation force on a spherical droplet:

\[F_{ac} = \frac{4\pi r^3}{3} \cdot \frac{p_0^2}{\rho_0 c^2} \cdot k \cdot \Phi\]

Where: - \(r\) = droplet radius (0.5-2mm typical) - \(p_0\) = pressure amplitude (2-3 kPa) - \(\rho_0\) = medium density (1.2 kg/m³ for air) - \(c\) = sound speed (343 m/s at 20°C) - \(k\) = wave number (2π/λ) - \(\Phi\) = acoustic contrast factor

docs.title: Acoustic Contrast Factor
docs.text:
For liquid metal droplets in air:

\[\Phi = \frac{1}{3}\left[\frac{5\rho_p - 2\rho_0}{2\rho_p + \rho_0} - \frac{\beta_0}{\beta_p}\right]\]

Typical values: - Aluminum: Φ ≈ 0.85 - Steel: Φ ≈ 0.91 - Lead: Φ ≈ 0.93

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This FMEA identifies potential failure modes, their effects, and mitigation strategies for the Acoustic Manufacturing System.

docs.title: Risk Priority Number (RPN) Calculation
docs.text:
RPN = Severity × Occurrence × Detection

  • Severity (S): 1-10 (10 = catastrophic)
  • Occurrence (O): 1-10 (10 = very frequent)
  • Detection (D): 1-10 (10 = undetectable)

docs.title: Component
docs.text:
Individual component data structure.

@dataclass
class Component:
    name: str
    category: ComponentCategory
    type: ComponentType
    specification: str
    quantity: int
    unit_cost: float
    total_cost: float
    supplier: str
    tech_specs: Optional[TechnicalSpecs] = None

docs.title: TechnicalSpecs
docs.text:
Detailed technical specifications.

@dataclass
class TechnicalSpecs:
    # Electrical
    power_consumption: Optional[float] = None  # Watts
    power_supply: Optional[float] = None  # Watts (for PSUs)
    voltage_nominal: Optional[float] = None  # V

    # Physical
    weight: Optional[float] = None  # kg
    dimensions: Optional[Dict[str, float]] = None  # mm

    # Thermal
    operating_temp: Optional[Tuple[float, float]] = None  # (min, max) °C
    max_temp: Optional[float] = None  # °C

    # Performance
    efficiency: Optional[float] = None  # %
    frequency: Optional[float] = None  # Hz

docs.title: Getting Components
docs.text:
from models.component_registry import ComponentRegistry, ComponentCategory

# Initialize registry
registry = ComponentRegistry()

# Get all acoustic components
acoustic_components = [
    c for c in registry.components 
    if c.category == ComponentCategory.ACOUSTIC
]

# Get total cost
total_cost = sum(c.total_cost for c in registry.components)

docs.title: Power Analysis
docs.text:
# Calculate power budget
power_budget = registry.calculate_power_budget()

# Get net power consumption
net_power = power_budget['TOTAL']['net_power']
print(f"Net power consumption: {net_power}W")

# Check thermal dissipation
thermal_validation = registry.validate_thermal_design()
total_heat = thermal_validation['total_heat_generation']

docs.title: Interface

@dataclass

docs.title: get_interfaces_by_subsystem(subsystem: str) -> List[Interface]
docs.text: Get all interfaces involving a subsystem.

docs.title: Usage Examples
docs.text:
from models.interfaces.interface_registry import get_interface, SYSTEM_INTERFACES

# Get specific interface
icd = get_interface("ICD-001")
print(f"Interface: {icd.name}")
print(f"Criticality: {icd.criticality.value}")

# Check requirements
for req in icd.requirements:
    print(f"{req.parameter}: {req.nominal} {req.units}")

from models.interfaces.icd_generator import ICDGenerator

docs.title: InterfaceValidator
docs.text:
Validate interface compatibility.

class InterfaceValidator:
    def validate_interface(self, interface: Interface) -> Tuple[bool, List[str]]:
        """Validate single interface"""

    def validate_all_interfaces(self) -> Tuple[bool, List[Dict]]:
        """Validate all system interfaces"""

    def generate_validation_report(self) -> str:
        """Generate validation report"""

docs.title: Usage Examples
docs.text:
from models.interfaces.interface_validator import InterfaceValidator

# Validate all interfaces
validator = InterfaceValidator()
valid, results = validator.validate_all_interfaces()

if not valid:
    for result in results:
        if not result['valid']:
            print(f"{result['icd']}: {len(result['issues'])} issues")

# Generate report
report = validator.generate_validation_report()

docs.title: Power Calculations
docs.text:
def calculate_net_power(consumption: float, supply: float) -> float:
    """Calculate net power requirement"""
    return consumption - supply

docs.title: Temperature Conversions
docs.text:
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius: float) -> float:
    """Convert Celsius to Fahrenheit"""
    return celsius * 9/5 + 32

def fahrenheit_to_celsius(fahrenheit: float) -> float:
    """Convert Fahrenheit to Celsius"""
    return (fahrenheit - 32) * 5/9

docs.title: Acoustic Calculations
docs.text:
def wavelength(frequency: float, speed: float = 343) -> float:
    """Calculate wavelength from frequency"""
    return speed / frequency

def pressure_to_db(pressure: float, reference: float = 20e-6) -> float:
    """Convert pressure to decibels"""
    return 20 * math.log10(pressure / reference)

docs.title: Export Instructions for Draw.io Diagrams
docs.text: This document explains how to export diagrams from Draw.io to static image formats.

docs.title: Current System Architecture Diagram
docs.text: The interactive system architecture diagram is embedded in the documentation at: - Location: System Architecture - File: docs/assets/diagrams/system_architecture.html

docs.title: Quick Export (PNG)
docs.text:
1. Open the System Architecture page
  2. In the embedded diagram viewer, look for the toolbar at the top
  3. Click the three dots menu (⋮) or export icon
  4. Select "Export as" → "PNG"
  5. Choose settings and download

docs.title: Opening in Draw.io Editor
docs.text:
1. In the embedded viewer, click the pencil icon (Edit)
  2. This opens the diagram in the Draw.io editor
  3. Make any necessary edits
  4. Export using File menu options

docs.title: PNG Export (Recommended for Documentation)
docs.text:
1. File → Export as → PNG
  2. Settings:
  3. Zoom: 200% (for high resolution)
  4. Width: 2400px
  5. Border: 10px
  6. Background: White
  7. DPI: 300 (if available)
  8. Save as: system_architecture.png
  9. Place in: docs/assets/images/

docs.title: SVG Export (Recommended for Scalability)
docs.text:
1. File → Export as → SVG
  2. Settings:
  3. Include a copy of my diagram: Yes
  4. Links: Open in new window
  5. Embed Images: Yes
  6. Embed Fonts: Yes
  7. Save as: system_architecture.svg
  8. Place in: docs/assets/images/

docs.title: PDF Export (For Printing)
docs.text:
1. File → Export as → PDF
  2. Settings:
  3. Page Size: A3 Landscape
  4. Fit to Page: Yes
  5. Include Grid: No
  6. Save as: system_architecture.pdf
  7. Place in: docs/assets/

docs.title: Updating the Interactive Diagram
docs.text:
When you need to update the embedded interactive diagram:

  1. Make changes in Draw.io
  2. File → Export as → HTML
  3. Settings:
  4. Lightbox: Yes
  5. Layers: Yes
  6. Pages: Current page only
  7. Border: 0
  8. Copy the entire HTML output
  9. Replace contents of docs/assets/diagrams/system_architecture.html
  10. Test the embedding in the documentation
  11. Commit both the HTML and a PNG backup

docs.title: File Naming Convention
docs.text: Use descriptive names for different versions: - system_architecture.html - Interactive main diagram - system_architecture_full.png - Full diagram export - system_architecture_subsystems.png - Subsystems only view - system_architecture_interfaces.png - Interface connections focus - system_architecture_simplified.svg - Simplified version for presentations

docs.title: Version Control Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always commit both interactive (HTML) and static (PNG) versions
  2. Use descriptive commit messages: 
    docs: Update system architecture diagram
- Added emergency shutdown connections
- Updated component colors for clarity
- Fixed ICD-010 interface routing
  3. Tag major diagram versions in git for reference

docs.title: Acoustic Force Calculation
docs.text:
The system will use the Gorkov potential for force calculation:

F = -4/3 × π × r³ × k × P² × ρ_contrast

Where: - r = droplet radius (0.5-1.0 mm) - k = wave number (2π/λ) - P = acoustic pressure amplitude - ρ_contrast = density contrast factor

docs.text:

  2. Cooling Rate Calculation: dT/dt from consecutive frames
  3. Solidification Prediction: Time to reach solidus temperature

docs.title: Multi-Droplet Coordination
docs.text:
Managing multiple droplets simultaneously requires careful coordination:

graph TD
    A[Droplet Tracker] -->|1kHz| B[Position Update]
    B --> C[Interference Check]
    C --> D{Collision Risk?}
    D -->|Yes| E[Emergency Redirect]
    D -->|No| F[Optimize Phases]
    F --> G[Apply Forces]

    H[Thermal Predictor] --> I[Future States]
    I --> C

docs.title: Coordination Algorithm
docs.text:
# Pseudo-code for multi-droplet control
for each control_cycle (1ms):
    # Track all droplets
    positions = tracker.scan_field()

    # Check interactions
    for i, j in droplet_pairs:
        distance = calculate_distance(i, j)
        if distance < critical_distance:
            if time_to_collision < 50ms:
                emergency_redirect(i, j)
            else:
                adjust_trajectories(i, j)

    # Optimize phase array
    phases = optimize_for_all_droplets(positions, targets)
    fpga.update_phases(phases)

docs.title: Emergency Shutdown Sequence
docs.text:
Critical safety procedure with parallel immediate actions:

sequenceDiagram
    participant ES as E-Stop Button
    participant SC as Safety Controller
    participant AS as Acoustic System
    participant TS as Thermal System
    participant VS as Ventilation

    ES->>SC: E-Stop Pressed (<1ms)

    par Immediate Actions
        SC->>AS: Cut Power (<5ms)
        and
        SC->>TS: Disable Heaters (<5ms)
        and
        SC->>VS: Max Exhaust (<10ms)
    end

    AS->>SC: Save Droplet States
    SC->>AS: Enable Catch Basin
    Note over AS: 2s gravity capture

    SC->>TS: Emergency Cooling
    SC->>SC: Log Incident
    SC->>ES: Confirm Safe State

docs.title: Shutdown Priorities
docs.text:
1. Immediate (<10ms)
  2. Cut acoustic power
  3. Disable all heating

  4. Activate ventilation

  5. Secondary (<100ms)

  6. Save system state
  7. Activate catch basins

  8. Begin forced cooling

  9. Tertiary (<1s)

  10. Complete logging
  11. Notify operators
  12. Prepare for restart

docs.title: Thermal Dynamics
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

docs.title: Droplet Cooling Model
docs.text: The thermal behavior of droplets in flight determines solidification timing and microstructure formation.

docs.title: Heat Transfer Mechanisms
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Droplet Heat Content] --> B[Convective Cooling]
    A --> C[Radiative Cooling]
    B --> D[Heat Loss Rate]
    C --> D
    D --> E[Temperature Change]

    F[Gas Velocity] --> B
    G[Surface Area] --> B
    G --> C
    H[Emissivity] --> C

docs.title: Cooling Rate Equation
docs.text:
The total cooling rate combines Newton's law of cooling with Stefan-Boltzmann radiation:

dT/dt = -(h·A·(T-T_amb) + ε·σ·A·(T⁴-T_amb⁴))/(m·c_p)

Where: - h = convection coefficient (W/m²·K) - A = surface area (m²) - T = droplet temperature (K) - T_amb = ambient temperature (300 K) - ε = emissivity (~0.3 for liquid metal) - σ = Stefan-Boltzmann constant - m = droplet mass (kg) - c_p = specific heat (J/kg·K)

docs.text:
graph LR

    A --> C[Specific Heat]
    A --> D[Density]
    A --> E[Viscosity]

    B --> F[Heat Transfer]
    C --> F
    D --> G[Mass/Volume]
    E --> H[Flow Behavior]

docs.title: Flight Time vs Temperature
docs.text:
# Example cooling calculation for 1mm Al droplet
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Parameters
r = 0.5e-3  # radius (m)
T0 = 973    # initial temp (K)
T_amb = 300 # ambient (K)
t = np.linspace(0, 0.2, 1000)  # 200ms flight

# Simplified exponential cooling
tau = 0.05  # time constant (s)
T = T_amb + (T0 - T_amb) * np.exp(-t/tau)

# Cooling rate
dTdt = -(T0 - T_amb) / tau * np.exp(-t/tau)

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 5))
plt.subplot(121)
plt.plot(t*1000, T-273, 'b-')
plt.xlabel('Time (ms)')
plt.ylabel('Temperature (°C)')
plt.title('Droplet Temperature')

plt.subplot(122)
plt.plot(t*1000, -dTdt, 'r-')
plt.axhline(1000, color='g', linestyle='--', label='SR010 Requirement')
plt.xlabel('Time (ms)')
plt.ylabel('Cooling Rate (K/s)')
plt.title('Cooling Rate')
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()

docs.title: Microstructure Prediction
docs.text:
Grain size correlates with cooling rate: 

d = A × (dT/dt)^n
Where: - d = average grain size - A = material constant (~100 μm) - dT/dt = cooling rate - n = exponent (~-0.5)

docs.title: Active Feedback Control
docs.text:
class ThermalController:
    def __init__(self):
        self.Kp = 10.0   # Proportional gain
        self.Ki = 0.1    # Integral gain
        self.Kd = 1.0    # Derivative gain
        self.integral = 0
        self.last_error = 0

    def update(self, setpoint, measured, dt):
        error = setpoint - measured
        self.integral += error * dt
        derivative = (error - self.last_error) / dt

        output = (self.Kp * error + 
                 self.Ki * self.integral + 
                 self.Kd * derivative)

        self.last_error = error
        return output

docs.title: 5.1 Test Equipment
docs.text:
• Hydrophone array
  • Thermal camera
  • Thermocouples

docs.title: 5.2 Test Procedure
docs.text:
1. Pre-Test Setup
  2. Verify all components installed correctly
  3. Check electrical connections and continuity
  4. Calibrate test equipment

  5. Document baseline conditions

  6. Baseline Measurements

  7. Measure Acoustic Transmission using Hydrophone measurement
    • Expected: 85 % (±10.0)
  8. Measure Thermal Leakage using Thermal imaging
    • Expected: 50 W (±50.0)

  9. Measure Transducer Temperature using Thermocouple monitoring

    • Expected: 40 °C (±20.0)

  10. Functional Verification

  11. Power on system incrementally
  12. Monitor all interface parameters
  13. Verify normal operation for 30 minutes

  14. Check for error conditions or alarms

  15. Stress Testing

  16. Gradually increase to maximum rated conditions
  17. Monitor for parameter drift or instability
  18. Verify parameters remain within specification

  19. Document any degradation or warnings

  20. Acceptance Testing

  21. Run full 4-hour endurance test
  22. Verify all requirements continuously met
  23. Document final measurements
  24. Generate acceptance report

docs.title: 5.3 Acceptance Criteria
docs.text:
• All parameters within specified min/max ranges
  • No thermal damage to components
  • Stable operation for 4+ hours
  • Interface meets all functional requirements

docs.title: Compatibility Status: ❌ INCOMPATIBLE
docs.text:
Critical Issues: - ❌ Extreme thermal mismatch: 1120°C difference between sides

Warnings: - ⚠️ 40kHz Transducers has max temp of 80°C - ensure adequate thermal isolation

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text: We welcome contributions to the Acoustic Manufacturing System documentation! This guide explains how to contribute effectively.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Git knowledge
  • Python 3.8+
  • Markdown familiarity
  • GitHub account

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Clone your fork: 
    git clone https://github.com/yourusername/drip.git
cd drip/acoustic-sysml-v2
  3. Create a branch: 
    git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
  4. Install dependencies: 
    pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Documentation Improvements
docs.text:
• Fix typos or errors
  • Improve clarity
  • Add examples
  • Update outdated information

docs.title: Code Contributions
docs.text:
• Bug fixes
  • New features
  • Performance improvements
  • Test additions

docs.title: Component Updates
docs.text:
• Add new components
  • Update specifications
  • Correct costs
  • Add suppliers

docs.title: Python Code
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8
  • Use type hints
  • Document all functions
  • Write unit tests

Example: 

def calculate_wavelength(frequency: float, speed: float = 343) -> float:
    """
    Calculate acoustic wavelength.

    Args:
        frequency: Frequency in Hz
        speed: Sound speed in m/s (default: air at 20°C)

    Returns:
        Wavelength in meters
    """
    return speed / frequency

docs.title: Markdown Style
docs.text:
• Use ATX headers (#)
  • Limit lines to 100 characters
  • Use fenced code blocks
  • Include alt text for images

docs.title: File Naming
docs.text:
• Use lowercase
  • Separate words with hyphens
  • Be descriptive but concise
  • Include file extension

Good: thermal-analysis.md Bad: ThermalAnalysis.MD

docs.title: Content Structure
docs.text:
1. Clear title
  2. Brief overview
  3. Detailed sections
  4. Examples/diagrams
  5. References

docs.title: Writing Style
docs.text:
• Active voice
  • Present tense
  • Concise sentences
  • Technical accuracy

docs.title: Before Submitting
docs.text:
1. Run tests: 

    python test_icd_system.py

  2. Check documentation: 

    python generate_mkdocs.py
mkdocs serve

  3. Validate interfaces: 

    python -m models.interfaces.interface_validator

docs.title: Documentation Tests
docs.text:
• Links work
  • Code examples run
  • Images display
  • Tables format correctly

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Title: Clear and descriptive
  2. Description: What and why
  3. Testing: What was tested
  4. Screenshots: If applicable

Template: 

## Description
Brief description of changes

## Type of Change
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] New feature
- [ ] Documentation update
- [ ] Performance improvement

## Testing
- [ ] Tests pass
- [ ] Documentation builds
- [ ] No warnings

## Screenshots
(if applicable)

docs.title: Review Process
docs.text:
1. Automated checks run
  2. Maintainer reviews
  3. Feedback addressed
  4. Changes merged

docs.title: Adding Components
docs.text:
new_component = Component(
    name="Component Name",
    category=ComponentCategory.ACOUSTIC,
    type=ComponentType.COTS,
    specification="Part number",
    quantity=1,
    unit_cost=100.00,
    total_cost=100.00,
    supplier="Supplier Name",
    tech_specs=TechnicalSpecs(
        power_consumption=10,
        weight=0.5,
        operating_temp=(0, 50)
    )
)

docs.text:
1. Modify interface_registry.py
  2. Update requirements
  3. Regenerate documentation
  4. Validate changes

docs.text:
1. Edit component power specs
  2. Run power calculator
  3. Update documentation
  4. Verify totals

docs.title: Add Test Procedure

1. Create procedure in verification/procedures/
  2. Update test matrix
  3. Link from verification page
  4. Add to nav menu

docs.title: Fix Documentation Error
docs.text:
1. Find file in docs/
  2. Make correction
  3. Test locally
  4. Submit PR

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues for bugs
  • Discussions for questions
  • Email for private matters

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text: Include: - Clear title - Steps to reproduce - Expected behavior - Actual behavior - Environment details

docs.title: Feature Requests
docs.text:
• Use GitHub Issues
  • Label as "enhancement"
  • Describe use case
  • Propose solution

docs.title: Our Standards
docs.text:
• Respectful communication
  • Constructive feedback
  • Inclusive environment
  • Professional behavior

docs.title: Unacceptable Behavior
docs.text:
• Harassment
  • Discrimination

docs.title: Documentation Editing Guide
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

This documentation includes an interactive editing feature that allows authorized users to make changes directly in the browser.

docs.title: Method 1: Keyboard Shortcut
docs.text: Press Ctrl+E (or Cmd+E on Mac) to toggle edit mode on/off.

docs.title: Method 2: Edit Button
docs.text:
Click the edit icon in the header toolbar to toggle edit mode.

Edit Mode Indicator

When edit mode is active, you'll see:

  • An "EDIT MODE" badge in the top-right corner
  • Editable content highlighted on hover
  • A save button in the header showing the number of unsaved edits

docs.title: Making Edits
docs.text:
1. Enable edit mode using one of the methods above
  2. Click any text to start editing:
  3. Headers (H1-H6)
  4. Paragraphs
  5. List items
  6. Table cells

  7. Admonition content

  8. Type your changes directly in the browser

  9. Click outside the element to finish editing

Editing Tips

  • Press Esc to cancel editing the current element
  • Press Tab to move to the next editable element
  • Use Ctrl+Z to undo changes within an element

docs.title: Export Edits
docs.text: Click the save button in the header (or press Ctrl+S) to download your edits as a JSON file.

docs.title: Apply Edits to Source Files
docs.text:
To apply your edits back to the source markdown files:

# Download the edits JSON file from the browser
# Then run:
python apply_edits.py docs-edits-[timestamp].json

# For a dry run (preview changes without applying):
python apply_edits.py docs-edits-[timestamp].json --dry-run

Important Notes

  • Edits are stored locally in your browser until exported
  • Clearing browser data will lose unsaved edits
  • Complex formatting may need manual adjustment after applying
  • Always review changes before committing to version control

docs.title: Visual Indicators
docs.text: Indicator Meaning Blue outline on hover Content is editable Blue shadow when focused Currently editing Red asterisk (*) Unsaved changes Number badge on save button Count of unsaved edits

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Shortcut Action Ctrl+E Toggle edit mode Ctrl+S Save all edits Esc Cancel current edit Tab Next editable element Shift+Tab Previous editable element

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
The editor currently supports:

  • • Plain text editing
  • • Basic formatting preservation
  • • Local storage of edits
  • • Export/import functionality

Not yet supported:

  • ❌ Rich text formatting (bold, italic, etc.)
  • ❌ Adding new sections
  • ❌ Editing code blocks
  • ❌ Editing Mermaid diagrams
  • ❌ Real-time collaboration

docs.title: Edits Not Appearing
docs.text:
1. Ensure edit mode is enabled
  2. Check if the element is editable (hover should show blue outline)
  3. Try refreshing the page

docs.title: Lost Edits
docs.text:
• Edits are saved in browser local storage
  • Use the same browser to recover unsaved edits
  • Export regularly to prevent data loss

docs.title: Apply Script Errors
docs.text:
• Ensure the docs directory structure hasn't changed
  • Check that the JSON file is valid
  • Review failed edits in the script output

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Export frequently to avoid losing work
  2. Review changes before applying to source files
  3. Test locally before pushing to production
  4. Keep backups - the apply script creates automatic backups
  5. Coordinate with team to avoid conflicting edits

The edit feature is designed for quick content updates. For structural changes or complex formatting, edit the source markdown files directly.

docs.title: A
docs.text: Acoustic Levitation The use of acoustic radiation pressure to suspend objects in mid-air against gravity. Acoustic Streaming Time-averaged flow induced by acoustic waves in a fluid medium. Acceptance Criteria Specific requirements that must be met for system acceptance. Archimedes Test Method to measure material density using fluid displacement.

docs.title: B
docs.text: BOM (Bill of Materials) Complete list of components, parts, and materials needed to build the system. Build Volume Maximum size of object that can be manufactured by the system.

docs.title: C
docs.text: CTE (Coefficient of Thermal Expansion) The rate at which a material expands when heated. COTS (Commercial Off-The-Shelf) Standard components available from suppliers without modification. Crucible Container for holding molten material at high temperature.

docs.title: D
docs.text: Droplet Small volume of molten material manipulated by acoustic field. Duty Cycle Ratio of active time to total cycle time.

docs.title: F
docs.text: FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) Algorithm to compute frequency spectrum from time-domain signal. FMEA (Failure Mode and Effects Analysis) Systematic analysis of potential failure modes and their impacts. FPGA (Field-Programmable Gate Array) Reprogrammable integrated circuit used for real-time control.

docs.title: H
docs.text: Hydrophone Underwater microphone used to measure acoustic pressure.

docs.title: I
docs.text: ICD (Interface Control Document) Formal specification of the interface between two subsystems. Impedance Matching Technique to maximize power transfer between components. Induction Heating Heating conductive materials using electromagnetic induction.

docs.title: L
docs.text: Levitation Suspension of object without physical support.

docs.title: M
docs.text: MTBF (Mean Time Between Failures) Average time between system failures.

docs.title: P
docs.text: Phased Array Array of transducers with individually controlled phase to shape acoustic field. Pyrometer Non-contact temperature measurement device.

docs.title: R
docs.text: RMS (Root Mean Square) Statistical measure of varying quantity magnitude. RPN (Risk Priority Number) Product of severity, occurrence, and detection ratings in FMEA.

docs.title: S
docs.text: Standing Wave Wave pattern resulting from interference of two waves traveling in opposite directions. STM32 Family of 32-bit microcontrollers from STMicroelectronics.

docs.title: T
docs.text: THD (Total Harmonic Distortion) Measure of signal distortion due to harmonics. Transducer Device that converts electrical energy to acoustic energy (ultrasonic). TRL (Technology Readiness Level) Scale measuring technology maturity from 1 (basic) to 9 (proven).

docs.title: U
docs.text: Ultrasonic Sound waves above human hearing range (>20 kHz).

docs.title: V
docs.text: VSWR (Voltage Standing Wave Ratio) Measure of impedance matching in transmission lines.

docs.title: W
docs.text: Wavelength Distance between repeating points of a wave (λ = c/f).

docs.title: Safety Requirements and Procedures
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

docs.title: High Voltage Systems (220V AC)
docs.text:
• Main power input rated at 63A
  • Ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) required
  • Electrical isolation barriers mandatory
  • Arc flash protection required for maintenance

docs.title: Low Voltage DC Systems
docs.text:
• 48V DC main distribution (up to 200A)
  • Touch-safe connectors required
  • Overcurrent protection on all branches
  • Emergency shutdown capability

docs.title: High Temperature Zones
docs.text:
• Crucible system: up to 1500°C operational
  • Heated bed: up to 850°C operational
  • Induction heater: 3kW power, surface temps >200°C

docs.title: Safety Measures
docs.text:
• Thermal barriers and insulation
  • Emergency cooling procedures
  • Personnel protection equipment
  • Temperature monitoring and alarms

docs.title: Ultrasonic Exposure
docs.text:
• 40kHz transducers at high power levels
  • Potential for heating effects in tissues
  • Hearing protection in operational areas
  • Exposure time limits for personnel

docs.title: Chemical Hazards
docs.text:
• Material feed systems may contain hazardous substances
  • Proper ventilation required
  • Material safety data sheets (MSDS) available
  • Spill containment procedures

docs.title: Mechanical Hazards
docs.text:
• Moving parts in feed systems
  • High pressure systems
  • Pinch points and crush hazards
  • Lockout/tagout procedures required

docs.title: Power Emergency
docs.text:
1. Activate emergency stop
  2. Disconnect main power
  3. Verify all systems safe
  4. Document incident

docs.title: Thermal Emergency
docs.text:
1. Activate emergency cooling
  2. Shut down heating systems
  3. Evacuate area if necessary
  4. Contact emergency services

docs.title: Personnel Safety
docs.text:
1. Ensure area is safe
  2. Provide first aid if needed
  3. Contact medical services
  4. Document incident

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• Safety glasses with side shields
  • Heat-resistant gloves for thermal work
  • Hearing protection in acoustic areas
  • Steel-toed safety boots
  • Lab coats or protective clothing

docs.title: Special Operations
docs.text:
• Full face shield for high temperature work
  • Insulated gloves for electrical work
  • Respiratory protection for material handling
  • Arc flash suits for electrical maintenance

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Acoustic Manufacturing System uses ultrasonic levitation to manipulate molten metal droplets in a contactless manner.

docs.text:
graph TB
    subgraph "Input"
        MAT[Material Feed]
        PWR[Power Supply<br/>10kW]
        CTRL[Control PC]

        MELT[Melting System<br/>3kW Induction]

docs.title: Acoustic Subsystem
docs.text:
• Function: Generate 40kHz standing waves for droplet manipulation
  • Components: {ComponentRegistry(1).get_level_transducer_count()}-{ComponentRegistry(4).get_level_transducer_count()} ultrasonic transducers in phased array
  • Control: FPGA-based phase control with <100μs update rate
  • Power: {ComponentRegistry(1).get_level_transducer_count() * 10}W (Level 1) to {ComponentRegistry(4).get_level_transducer_count() * 10}W (Level 4)

docs.title: Thermal Subsystem
docs.text:
• Function: Melt material and control solidification
  • Range: 700-1580°C operating temperature
  • Heating: 8kW resistive (Al) + 3kW induction (Steel)
  • Monitoring: Optris PI 1M thermal camera at 32Hz

docs.title: Control Subsystem
docs.text:
• Architecture: Hierarchical (PC → STM32 → FPGA)
  • Loop Rate: 1kHz primary control loop
  • Feedback: Thermal imaging + acoustic field mapping
  • Interface: Gigabit Ethernet + USB 3.0

docs.title: Power Subsystem
docs.text:
• Capacity: 10kW PSU with 91% efficiency
  • Distribution: 48V primary, 24V/12V/5V secondary
  • Protection: Over-current, over-temp, EMI filtering
  • Net Consumption: 4.6kW (Level 1)

docs.title: Material Feed Subsystem
docs.text:
• Capacity: 25 parallel material outlets
  • Control: Automated valve sequencing
  • Materials: Al, Steel, Ti, Cu, Ni (Level 4)
  • Feed Rate: Variable 0.1-10 g/min

docs.text:

        STM[STM32<br/>Device Interface]
        FPGA[Cyclone IV<br/>Real-time Control]
    end

    subgraph "Actuators"
        TR[Transducers]
        HT[Heaters]
        VL[Valves]
    end

    TC --> PC
    TS --> STM
    PS --> STM

    PC --> STM
    STM --> FPGA

    FPGA --> TR
    STM --> HT
    STM --> VL

    style FPGA fill:#4caf50

docs.title: Acceptance Criteria
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

docs.title: System Level Acceptance Planning
docs.text: The Acoustic Manufacturing System Level 1 will need to meet all acceptance criteria before proceeding to Level 2 development.

docs.title: Acoustic Performance
docs.text:
• 📋 Frequency Accuracy: 40kHz ±100Hz to be verified
  • Field Uniformity: ±5% in 80% of build volume
  • 📋 Power Delivery: 10W per transducer target
  • Phase Control: <1° phase error between channels
  • Stability: <1% drift over 8 hours

docs.title: Thermal Performance
docs.text:
• 📋 Temperature Range: 700-1580°C to be demonstrated
  • Temperature Stability: ±10°C at setpoint
  • 📋 Heating Rate: >50°C/min target
  • 📋 Cooling Rate: >1000°C/s to be verified
  • Thermal Uniformity: <50°C gradient in melt zone

docs.title: Material Processing
docs.text:
• Droplet Size: 1-3mm diameter controlled
  • 📋 Position Accuracy: ±0.3mm to be demonstrated
  • Deposition Rate: 1 cm³/hr minimum
  • Material Density: >95% theoretical
  • Surface Finish: <50μm Ra

docs.title: System Integration
docs.text:
• Control Latency: <100μs loop time
  • Data Logging: 1kHz minimum rate
  • User Interface: All functions accessible
  • Safety Interlocks: All operational
  • Emergency Stop: <100ms response

docs.title: Performance Metrics
docs.text: Metric Target Minimum Measured Status Build Volume 125 cm³ 100 cm³ ___ cm³ ⬜ Build Rate 1 cm³/hr 0.8 cm³/hr ___ cm³/hr ⬜ Power Consumption <5kW <6kW ___ kW ⬜ Positioning Accuracy ±0.3mm ±0.5mm ___ mm ⬜ Material Density >95% >93% ___ % ⬜ Operating Time 8 hrs 4 hrs ___ hrs ⬜

  • Surface Quality: No visible defects

  • Repeatability: <5% variation between builds
  • Material Properties: Within 10% of wrought

docs.title: System Reliability
docs.text:
• MTBF: >100 hours demonstrated
  • Availability: >90% during testing
  • False Alarm Rate: <1 per day
  • Data Integrity: No corruption events
  • Recovery Time: <30 minutes from failure

docs.title: Technical Documentation
docs.text:
• Operating Manual: Complete and reviewed
  • Maintenance Manual: All procedures documented

docs.title: Pre-Acceptance Review
docs.text:
1. Verify all component testing complete
  2. Review all open issues (must be <5 minor)
  3. Confirm documentation complete
  4. Schedule acceptance test (2 days)

docs.title: Acceptance Test Sequence
docs.text:
Day 1: Functional Tests - Morning: Acoustic system verification - Afternoon: Thermal system verification

Day 2: Performance Tests - Morning: Build test parts (5 minimum) - Afternoon: Evaluate parts and data

docs.title: Acceptance Decision
docs.text:
Pass Criteria: - All functional requirements met - >80% performance metrics achieved - No safety issues identified - Documentation complete

Conditional Pass: - Minor issues with mitigation plan - Performance >70% with improvement path - Documentation >90% complete

Fail Criteria: - Safety issues unresolved - Major functional failures - Performance <70% of target

docs.title: Test Procedures
docs.text:
PLANNING DOCUMENTATION ONLY

No hardware exists. No simulations completed. These are conceptual targets only.

Test Status: Planning Only

  • Hardware: Not available
  • Simulations: Not yet performed
  • Expected Execution: After prototype assembly (Q2 2025 or later)
  • Current Status: Defining test procedures and acceptance criteria

docs.title: Pre-Test Preparation
docs.text:
1. Will verify all safety systems operational
  2. Will check calibration certificates current
  3. Will review test procedure with team
  4. Will prepare data collection sheets
  5. Will verify environmental conditions

docs.title: Test Environment
docs.text:
• Temperature: 20±5°C
  • Humidity: 30-70% RH
  • Vibration: <0.1g RMS
  • EMI: Controlled environment
  • Power: Stable ±5%

docs.title: TP-001: Acoustic Frequency Verification
docs.text:
Purpose: Will verify transducer array operates at 40kHz ±100Hz

Equipment: - Oscilloscope with FFT capability - Current probe - Hydrophone (optional)

Procedure: 1. Power on acoustic system at 50% power 2. Allow 10 minutes warmup 3. Connect current probe to transducer drive 4. Capture waveform (10ms window) 5. Perform FFT analysis 6. Record peak frequency 7. Repeat for all 18 transducers 8. Increase to 100% power 9. Verify frequency stability

Pass Criteria: - Frequency: 40kHz ±100Hz - All transducers within ±50Hz - <1% drift over 1 hour

docs.title: TP-002: Acoustic Field Uniformity
docs.text:
Purpose: Will verify acoustic field uniformity within specifications

Equipment: - Hydrophone array (3×3 minimum) - 3-axis positioning system - Data acquisition system

Procedure: 1. Fill chamber with standard atmosphere 2. Position hydrophone at center 3. Energize transducers at nominal power 4. Record pressure amplitude 5. Move hydrophone in 10mm grid 6. Map entire build volume 7. Calculate uniformity metrics 8. Generate 3D field plot

Pass Criteria: - Central 80% volume: ±5% uniformity - No dead zones >5mm diameter - Symmetric field pattern

docs.title: TP-003: Temperature Range Validation
docs.text:
Purpose: Verify system achieves required temperature range

Equipment: - Type R thermocouples (3) - Data logger - Thermal camera

Procedure: 1. Install thermocouples in crucible 2. Start with ambient temperature 3. Ramp heating at 50°C/min 4. Record temperatures every second 5. Hold at 700°C for 10 minutes 6. Continue ramp to 1580°C 7. Hold for 5 minutes 8. Emergency cooling test 9. Verify cooling rate >1000°C/s

Pass Criteria: - Achieves 700°C for aluminum - Achieves 1580°C for steel - Stable temperature control ±10°C - No thermal runaway

docs.title: TP-004: Position Accuracy Test
docs.text:
Purpose: Verify droplet positioning accuracy

Equipment: - High-speed camera (>1000 fps) - Calibration grid - Image analysis software

Procedure: 1. Place calibration grid in view 2. Generate test droplet (2mm diameter) 3. Command position changes: - X: -10, -5, 0, +5, +10mm - Y: -10, -5, 0, +5, +10mm - Z: -5, 0, +5mm 4. Record actual positions 5. Calculate positioning error 6. Test dynamic tracking 7. Verify response time

Pass Criteria: - Static accuracy: ±0.3mm - Dynamic accuracy: ±0.5mm - Response time: <100ms - No oscillation/instability

docs.title: TP-005: Power Consumption Analysis
docs.text:
Purpose: Verify power consumption within budget

Equipment: - 3-phase power analyzer - Current probes - Data logger

Procedure: 1. Connect analyzer to main power 2. Start with system idle 3. Record baseline power 4. Energize subsystems sequentially: - Control system only - Add acoustic system - Add heating system - Add cooling system 5. Run at full power for 1 hour 6. Record power factor 7. Calculate efficiency

Pass Criteria: - Idle power: <500W - Full power: <5kW net consumption - Power factor: >0.95 - Efficiency: >90%

docs.title: Testing Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always verify calibration before testing
  2. Document unexpected observations immediately
  3. Take photos of all test setups
  4. Save raw data before any processing
  5. Use version control for analysis scripts

docs.title: Common Issues Encountered
docs.text:
• Electromagnetic interference affecting measurements
  • Temperature drift during long tests
  • Inconsistent grounding causing noise
  • Software crashes losing data

docs.title: Improvement Recommendations
docs.text:
• Implement automated data collection
  • Add redundant measurement channels
  • Improve EMI shielding
  • Regular software updates
